This is nowhere near enough detail in your commit message.  Key things to answer:

1. Why are you doing this?
2. What value does it add?
3. What impacts will it have to users (both developers and clients)
4. How did you test this change?

A quick count shows 140 places in code where we have /redfish/v1/Systems/system hardcoded.  This patchset makes fixes to maybe 20% of those.  This on its own is not a huge deal, but it makes me believe that the development process was to change "system" for the host id, then take a look at what broken and fix things one at a time for power and System.  This kind of approach isn't going to be acceptable for a feature like this, and I have no interest in merging a series that breaks the behavior of the sub-resource groups for a migration as major as this, given that it leads to continued inconsistencies, and is going to require the community to continue to help.

If your intent with this patch was to start the migration, and show one or two examples of how we could handle these cases better, GREAT!  Love the effort and the attempt to get early feedback on high level design decisions that have impact to a large number of call sites.  Ideally, you would've called this out in the commit message, but eh.

If the goal for this patchset is "fix the things that I need and ignore the rest, including the broken routes on my system" that's not going to work for me.


FWIW, I have multi-host Redfish systems coming up in the future, so as you develop code, design docs, or anything else in that realm, feel free to CC me on the reviews for those.  As I have time, I'm even willing to help write patches, you're just a little ahead of us.
Looking like a great start on the coding portion.  I suspect we need to discuss a little more about "strategy" around getting this hardcoded wart excised from bmcweb.

Hi Ed, This change is initial patch of multiple patches to extend redfish core library  support for multi host bmc systems. This change done in "systems.hpp" which has the logic for discovery of number host systems.so we have pushed this patch as first step. we can take any inputs/suggestions from community and once this is finalised we can submit the rest of the patches regarding multi host system support.

That sounds great!  That kind of detail would help a lot to add in your commit message, to make clear that:

1. This is the first in a series, and doesn't really stand alone.
2. Long term, we will move over all the resources to a non-hardcoded route.

As far as engaging with the community, asking questions on the discord bmcweb channel would be a great start.

Per the developing guide, please don't do string manipulations of these kinds of things when we have:

A. Generic classes for handling this stuff in a type safe way that handles encoding and decoding properly, to the HTTP RFC.
B. Generic utilities for doing this kinds of manipulation and field picking.

Why would the computerSystemIndex ever be empty?  I suspect this functions existence is pointing at the larger design problem that this patchset doesn't use the mapper, and once that's done, this method won't need to exist.
we have a URL class for these kinds of URL manipulations, please use it.

It seems like at some place in here we need to do some verification that <str> is valid.  Otherwise someone could request `/redfish/v1/Systems/NotASystem` and it is going to attempt something, isn't it?  Should the `getComputerSystemIndex` do some verification and return an empty string if the name isn't "systemN"?  I didn't see any code in `getComputerSystemIndex` that explicitly picked off the integer portion.  Was that missing?

Common error #11.

Yes, we need to validate this, but we should be doing it using the mapper, the same way we do everywhere else.  Take a look at almost any other collection besides systems, and you'll find examples of the "right" way to do this validation.  

Also, because this would've popped up had you run the tests that COMMON_ERRORS.md requires you to write, please read and understand all the cases in that doc before proceeding.  You've broken several of them here, which tells me that you clearly didn't read the document as is recommended in the developing guide.

This is going to change the "Name" of the system for basically every deployed OpenBMC Redfish instance.  Please mention this as an impact in your commit message, and we can start a discussion about whether or not that's ok, if we need to make it configurable for clients that need the old behavior and whatnot.  As-written, i'm fairly certain this breaks webui-vue because of:

https://github.com/openbmc/webui-vue/issues/43

FWIW, webui-vue maintainers and contributors have had 18 months of warning that this change was coming, and in the meantime have only added more hardcoded resources, so while we should definitely discuss it, those that rely on protocol-ignoring clients can probably come up with ways to fix them in short order once this patch series lands.  I'm not of the mind to require a contributor that's adding things that obey the Redfish spec properly to have to do a bunch of mitigation and testing because one client ignored the spec.  Happy to discuss if there are easier paths to go down.

The name referenced here before is "system".I just assigned it to a variable before storing in the json object.so this is expected to keep the same name for single host as before but the multi hosts will have numbers added at the end of system such as system1,system2 etc. please correct me if any other way this will have impact the existing implementation.

Call that out in your commit message as an explicit design decision, and we can discuss more.  I suspect this is going to be important as we get to resources at depth 2+, because we can't really be doing a mapper call for every host resource, before querying the host that we actually care about.
Probably need validation on this one too?

I'm not really interested in maintaining the complexity that this entails of keeping two different naming schemes long term.  It means that for EVERY computersystem route (of which there are many), we'll need to determine if we're in single system mode, or double system mode, and for people implementing Redfish code on a single system (which are the majority) it's highly likely that they break the multi-host case, especially as we go deep into the tree (ie /redfish/v1/Systems/systemN/LogServices/EventLog/Entries/entryN.  If I'm overestimating the complexity here, please let me know.  Realistically, interface-wise, a single system should look the same as having a single node in a multi-node system.

What I'd like to see is an analysis of the existing dbus and filesystem paths for host control that are used within the ComputerSystem tree;  Most of them are going to be called "xyz/openbmc_project/hostN" and given that Redfish generally uses the last part of that path as the control, we should be able to just change /redfish/v1/Systems/system to /redfish/v1/Systems/hostN without a problem in the long term.  In the short term, I suspect the best strategy would be to simply string replace "host0" with "system", so that "system" always represents the first node, and for any subsequent paths in the tree, "system" will be correct (at least in redfish terms) for both multi-node, and non-multi-node, with "system" (ie node0) just supporting more features than the rest of the nodes in the interim.

From my perspective this accomplishes:
1. A reasonably self-contained initial patchset where we can add multi-host support without breaking most of the tree, or having routes that are totally invalid and return 500 on multi-node systems.
2. A transition path to where individual nodes can be made "multi host aware" over time, and we can track our progress toward that goal with a simple

grep BMCWEB_ROUTE("/redfish/v1/Systems/system

As long as that call returns routes, this feature is still not done, and we still have routes we need to migrate to be multi-node aware (ie "redfish/v1/Systems/<str>")

3. Once all the routes have been migrated, we can simply remove the code that replaces host0 with "system", the IDs will change, and the tree will still be correct.

The above is what I have in my mind for a progressing path of this feature, and lets multiple people participate without getting in eachothers way.

> I'm not really interested in maintaining the complexity that this entails of keeping two different naming schemes long term.  It means that for EVERY computersystem route (of which there are many), we'll need to determine if we're in single system mode, or double system mode, and for people implementing Redfish code on a single system (which are the majority) it's highly likely that they break the multi-host case, especially as we go deep into the tree (ie /redfish/v1/Systems/systemN/LogServices/EventLog/Entries/entryN.  If I'm overestimating the complexity here, please let me know.  Realistically, interface-wise, a single system should look the same as having a single node in a multi-node system. 
> 
my idea is also to keeping single naming scheme by having the single host system with name system0 or host0.
Anyway as we have to migrate step by step we could keep the 
"system" name for single host for this time being.

> What I'd like to see is an analysis of the existing dbus and filesystem paths for host control that are used within the ComputerSystem tree;  Most of them are going to be called "xyz/openbmc_project/hostN" and given that Redfish generally uses the last part of that path as the control, we should be able to just change /redfish/v1/Systems/system to /redfish/v1/Systems/hostN without a problem in the long term.  In the short term, I suspect the best strategy would be to simply string replace "host0" with "system", so that "system" always represents the first node, and for any subsequent paths in the tree, "system" will be correct (at least in redfish terms) for both multi-node, and non-multi-node, with "system" (ie node0) just supporting more features than the rest of the nodes in the interim.

In my understanding Computer system tree is divided in the following two subparts:

1.Inventory items such as processors,RAM,storage,BIOS etc

These items are populated by probing the common inventory interfaces
such as xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Dimm,
xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Cpu etc.

My understanding is to gather the inventory item info at is redfish level
probing with these common inventory interfaces and filter the results based on host number. 

Populating the inventory item details under the respective dbus inventory 
path should be done separately and it is not within the scope of redfish.

2.Host Power control and host state components

almost all of the dbus object system paths associated with host control are having the same prefix "xyz/openbmc_project/hostN" as you have mentioned.

so this gerrit patch implemented host number based dbus object path in the "systems.hpp" and we have verified the applicable host control actions in our platform.

> 
> From my perspective this accomplishes:
> 1. A reasonably self-contained initial patchset where we can add multi-host support without breaking most of the tree, or having routes that are totally invalid and return 500 on multi-node systems.
> 2. A transition path to where individual nodes can be made "multi host aware" over time, and we can track our progress toward that goal with a simple
> 
> grep BMCWEB_ROUTE("/redfish/v1/Systems/system
> 
> As long as that call returns routes, this feature is still not done, and we still have routes we need to migrate to be multi-node aware (ie "redfish/v1/Systems/<str>")
> 
> 3. Once all the routes have been migrated, we can simply remove the code that replaces host0 with "system", the IDs will change, and the tree will still be correct.
> 
> The above is what I have in my mind for a progressing path of this feature, and lets multiple people participate without getting in eachothers way.

I think this change is in line with your proposal as well. I also think doing initial changes in systems.hpp is right start. If any specific change or deviation needed in the code, please let me know I will correct them.

>my idea is also to keeping single naming scheme by having the single host system with name system0 or host0.
Anyway as we have to migrate step by step we could keep the 
"system" name for single host for this time being.

This means we have to maintain two different sets of trees, "system" and "system0/host0" for which it's going to cause a lot of complexity.  Lets keep system0/host0 defined as "system" at a redfish level and follow the path I laid out, unless I'm over complicating it, but I've looked at it a bit in https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/53816 so i suspect this is a better way, and keeps most code consistent, and we can have a consistent rule in the meantime.

Hi All,If possible could you review this latest patch set regarding multi host bmcweb.
Thanks

Let us know that the migration plan for other redfish entries would be.

"/redfish/v1/Systems/system/" is hardcoded many places. More then in the lib/systems.

For example:

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/565dfb6f9a87e15fa707e6b2c89222c4419e7491/redfish-core/lib/storage.hpp#L31
Do you have further commits about how you link sub-resources (e.g., Memory, CPU) to a certain system?
at least for now only the probing with interfaces part of these inventory items are updated in the systems.hpp file.

The systems.hpp file has the discovery part, which discovers and populates computer systems. so this is the initial patch to propose this new change. If this proposal is approved other places using the hardcoded url will be also changed in the later patches.
why do you put these two functions into collection util? Seems specific to ComputerSystem
though it is related to computer systems , These are common util functions which may be used in other files as well.
Naveen...is there another patchset expected to address the remaining 3 unresolved comments?
All review comments are resolved with the last submitted patch. only I missed to close those three. just done it.

This patch is depends on the following patch: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/53816

I'm working on to resolve the merge conflicts of this patch.
nit: Why formatting was changed in this block?
Requesting a few changes and clarifications to this latest draft.
General comment...when adding a new parameter, the @param to match should be added to the @brief section before each function.  This should be done throughout this file.

currently only single host system is being represented by webui. all webui code only uses the name "system" which represents single host.so Ed has suggested we keep system as the first host name for the multi-host system for now.

is this should be getChassisServiceName() which will return a string as below?
"xyz.openbmc_project.State.Chassis" + computerSystemIndex

It results in compiler error. So I removed constexpr declaration.

wait, can we declare std:string constexpr now? I don't believe std::string satisfies "non-trivial destructor"

can we use std::string_view?

Can you follow the model of what was used on the line above, for systemToken?

You need to use a std::string_view object instead of a std::string object. Although it would make the most logical sense, our compiler is not new enough to allow std::string to be constexpr.

https://www.cppstories.com/2021/constexpr-vecstr-cpp20/

The string view will be viewing the literal "0" which is a C string literal. C string literals have static lifetime (equal to the program itself), so this is safe.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/9970295/life-time-of-a-string-literal-in-c

Ack, the string_view needs to be copied as a string while returning. this is because the result string will be concatenated with another string before usage.
I hope it is fine to declare as string_view and convert to string before returning.

> wait, can we declare std:string constexpr now? I don't believe std::string satisfies "non-trivial destructor"

Yes, std::string's constructor is now constexpr as of C++20.

> I hope it is fine to declare as string_view and convert to string before returning.

You shouldn't need an explicit conversion.  std::string can be converted from std::string_view, so just returning a string view will construct a string at the return site.

In any case, the issue you were running into was, unfortunately, with clang and not with gcc.  The clang-tidy stuff still doesn't correctly support constexpr strings.

When this function returns, yes, it should still return as std::string, because as you said the caller will need to modify it further. You can construct a std::string from a std::string_view just fine, and it will perform the copy at that time.

At any case, this is somewhat of a micro-optimization, and I would caution against bikeshedding. Unless this function is a performance hotspot, I'm OK with whatever, as long as the behavior is correct.

so that 
/redfish/v1/Systems/twin_lake_1
/redfish/v1/Systems/twin_lake_2
/redfish/v1/Systems/twin_lake_3

Right now Item.System is not used by many platforms comparing to the host power instances this patch has implemented. So we need to request all
the platforms to use Item.System with a common naming standard. 

specifically the host number needs to be appended at the end as follows

single host 
/redfish/v1/Systems/<host-name>_0

multihost
/redfish/v1/Systems/<host-name>_1
.
.
/redfish/v1/Systems/<host-name>_N

The specific host number is needed is because,
there are power control events like host power on/off and update current hoststate which are part of the "systems.hpp" and it requires the respective
host number to do the power control actions 

example "host" + computerSystemIndex is used for power restore policy

sdbusplus::asio::getProperty<std::string>(
        *crow::connections::systemBus, "xyz.openbmc_project.Settings",
        "/xyz/openbmc_project/control/host+ computerSystemIndex + /power_restore_policy",
        "xyz.openbmc_project.Control.Power.RestorePolicy", "PowerRestorePolicy",
        [aResp](const boost::system::error_code ec, const std::string& policy) {
        }
